metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value: Gallery OPENS  NEW EXHIBITION  result of Work Accompished by Civic Services Committee  An exhibition which is the cumination of a year"s study of the  assets, the architectural inheritance,  and the preservation problems of  Charleston open this afternoon at  the Gibbes art Gallery.  The exhibition is the result of  work done by the civic services  committee of the Carolina Art associaltion, which was organized in the  spring of 1940. The committee has  made a study of the physical units-  buildings, both Public and private,  parks, gardens, vistas-which go to  make up the tota asset of Charleston, has evaluated them according  to a scae of ratings, has card indexed them, and had commenced  the study of the means of preservation.  On being informed of the work  of the committee, the advisory  board on national parks, historic  sites, buildings, and monuments of  the national park service passed the  following resoution:  "Resoved, That the advisory  board approves in principe the  fine work accompished by the city .  planning committee [now civic  services committee] of the Carolina Art associaltion, as outined m  the letter of Helen G. McCormack,  secretary, of October 15, 1941, and  that it expresses the hope that the  exceent work may be continued  and brought to an adequate concusion."  The members of the civic services  committee are: Homer M. place,  chairman, E. Miby Burton, John  Mead Howes, Frederick H. McDonad, William M, Means, James  O"Hear, Sidney J. Rittenberg, Albert Simons, Miss Alice R. Huger  Smith, Samuel G. Stoney, Joseph I.  Waring, M, D, and Robert N. S.  Whitelaw.
